Pours hazy golden with notes of sweet malt that drive a deeper grain driven long finish. N

50cl bottle. Pours a clear dark caramel with an big white head. Smells roasted malt, and little nuttyness, sweet smell. Semi sweet taste and slightly bitter at the same time. Medium bodied, oily texture.  NICE BEER!

Very good for the style. Pours a dark brown with a white head. Looks great. The aroma has bread, caramel, roasted malt, a hint of chocolate. The flavor is similar with a nice balance to it. Nicely done.

Bottle from BigBox Twist. Reddish brown, minimal head. Aroma has roasted malts, some coffee and caramel.Some bitterness in the taste, with caramel, almonds. somewhat dry. Really nice beer, full bodied!

Bottle. Clear medium amber / brown color with a average frothy good lacing mostly lasting off-whitee head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, burnt, caramel, sweet. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter (malt bitter) with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft.

50cl bottle.
Pours a clear dark caramel with an offwhite head and excellent lacing.
Smells of caramel, roasted malt, and some nuttiness.
Tastes of a medium sweetness, with some bitterness; caramel, wood, roasted malt, nuts -- all very well balanced, and put together into a compelling beer.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, oily texture.
Finishes dry, with some bitter chestnut and roasted flavors.

Deep, dark ruby pour with a tin off-white head and lacing. Aromas of hops, malt, skunky, bread and hints of red grape. Bitter and slightly dry on the palate. Malt and hops are the main flavours, hint of fruity sweetness as the beer opens up. Easy drinking with medium carbonation. Not a lot to it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Sörspecialista, Budapest. Clear reddish brown color with creamy off-whie head. Pure roasted malty aroma with some caramel. Delicious dry taste. Light body with creamy texture and lively carbonation, Malty, caramel finish. Delicious roasted malty beer, a very good choise. Its a simple, but a good one. Not so complicated, a pure malty dark beer.

rotten eggs, cheese, spruce, cereal, ginger, butterscotch, vanilla, brown, cloudy, clear, rocky head, light sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, umami, full body, sticky, average carbonation, bitter, long finish,
Pours brown with a medium size head. Aroma of bready malt, caramel, dark fruits. Taste of sweet fruit, bread, nut. Solid, easy-drinking beer.

Bottle.  Deep amber body with a frothy beige head, mostly diminishing. Aroma of toasted grain, nuts, caramel with a hint of dark chocolate. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body turning thin in the finish, watery texture, soft carbonation. Bready beer with hints of cherries and cococa in the finish. Still, should be cleaner and bitterer in the finish which is also slightly chalky on the palate.

Bottle. Side-by-side with the Ayinger. Pours a deep coppery brown with an off-white head. The nose is toasty, chocolate notes and soft roast. Not exactly a "Dunkel," but really nice. Clean and fresh with a hint of hops. On tasting, balanced bitterness from both hops and faint roast. Cocoa and bread dominate. Really excellent beer, this one.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and its not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog!

Das Bier im Glas sieht ebenfalls super aus. Herrliches Rubinrot mit stabilem dunklem Schaum. Geruchlich kommts wie erwartet dominant malzig rüber. Der Antrunk ist ebenso. Herrliches Röstmalzaroma mit einem leicht bitteren Touch im Nachgeschmack, der aber keinesfalls übertrieben wirkt, sondern im Gegenteil, sehr angenehm. Es schmeckt doch sehr kräftig, jedoch ohne die Süffigkeit zu beeinschränken. Im Mittelteil wird der Nachgeschmack stärker schmeckend nach Röstmalz, die am Anfang erwähnte Bitterkeit verfliegt nach und nach.

(Bottle, 0.5 l, 20120206) The beer poured dark brown and clear. Its head was medium sized, sizzling and lightly brown. Aroma had caramell, molasses and a bit of roasted malts. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were roasted malts, molasses, caramell, grass and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty, sweet and mildly bitter. Easily drinkable beer with long lasting taste.

Aroma e coloração amadeirados, esta breja possue um sabor forte e meio agressivo, não colaborando com um bom paladar e degustação devida. Retrogosto afirma a agressividade, parece que a bebida lhe diz "não me beba" a cada gole.
Brown color with an average brown head. Malty aroma and taste, with toffee notes.

50cl bottle. Brown colour with a good formation but quickly diminishes light brown head. Aroma is malty, toasty and bready. Flavour has hints of nuts and almonds. Dense on palate, it is sweet at the beginning, maintained in the final. Carbonation is soft to medium. Body is medium to high. Texture is oily.
Kopparförgad öl med, gulbeige skum. Söt maltig doft, råsocker. Även maltig smak med rostade toner. Något för söt för högre betyg från mig.
Clear dark reddish brown with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and nutty. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. Soft and pleasant. 171211

A deep mahogany pour with a frothy, tan head.  It has an all malt aroma with some light caramel.  The medium body has a slick texture with average carbonation.  The sweet taste gets a little roasted in the finish.

Bottle by 14.03.2012.  Nose is sweet brown sugar and dark malt, heavy caramel with raisin and very faint smoke and ash.  Dark ruby body with a sudsy tan head.  Taste is lightly bitter with a big nutty component, sweet fruit fades into dryness.  Less caramel, more heavy earth, even nearing saltiness.  Richly malty medium body with light tang and some ash in the after.  Superb and elegant.

Date: November 21, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Binnys Description: Semi-opaque dark brown pour with some head and spotty lacing, roasted malty, nutty and dark fruit aroma, taste was similar, medium to full bodied, slight carbonation.
Bottled 50cl. Ordered from www.bierzwerg.de. Not the most in interesting example of the style. Decent.
Dark brown pour with mahogany highlights.  Thin off-white rim for a head.  Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, and nuts.  Toasted malt and nut flavor with some caramel sweetness.  Overall, a nice beer.

Bottle. Pours ruby red with small off white head. Nose is strong raisin, toffee, and brown sugar. Flavors are much of the same, strong rich raisin and toffee while booze and tannins meet heavily, some ash finishes to help dry it out a little. Rather heavy body. A rich dunkel, lots of unfermentables here leaving this as flavorful as most dopplebocks.
Red-brown, beige foam with strong sheeting lacing.  Toast, nutty, caramels, some light metallic malt.  Taste is a bit thin, some cocoa, caramel, bready, a bit of metal again.

Bottle, from Fenaknoken, Oslo. Pours a deep copper brown, red-hued body with a big creamy white head. Nose is roasty caramel malts, toffee, worty graints and hints of strawberries and burnt almonds. Taste is caramel, roasted malts, grains, wort, hints of burnt almonds. Very smooth carbonation, full mouthfeel. A very nice Dunkel indeed.
Pours mahogany brown with an off-white head. Aroma is caramelized sugar and chocolate malt. Taste is less sweet, more roasted malt.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful dark reddish brown, with a thick creamy head. Pleasant aroma of chocolate and caramel. Flavour is burned malts and sugar, with good notes of caramel, nuts and chocolate. Finishes of with a burned maltiness.
Bottle. Clear dark brown pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is slightly roasted, caramel, dark fruits and some nuts. Flavor is dry, slightly bitter and full bodied. Very nice balance.

Aroma is chocolate, caramal, roast and spices.
Flavour is loads of caramel, some chocolate.
Nice dunkel.
Bottle.Brown colour with medium white head.Aroma is bready and sweet with taste of sugar and nuts,sweet malty and light tosted good smooth mouthfeels and light finish.

Nasal malzig mit süßlichen Einflüssen und eichenholzbehaftet. Das Bier greift malzig und trocken an, erscheint im weiteren Geschmacksverlauf aber auch brotig. Der Abgang punktet mit nussigen Nuancen. 
Leichte Mängel im Geschmacksbild, aber so weit in Ordnung. Test vom 8.12.2007

Cola brown beer with a almost medium and blond head. Aroma is balanced and tastefull, rye breads, dark malts and chocolate. Taste is dark malty, rye breads and in the aftertaste there are some nice chocolate sweetness. Quite smooth and surprisingly great bodied beer. Very balanced and enjoyable beer, true high quality from Germany.
Bottle 500ml. Color dark amber with big head. Aroma caramel, malt, sugar, dark fruits. Taste roasted, caramel, sweet, chocolate.

Appearance:  medium amber-brown, short off-white head, bits of lace.  Aroma: molasses, dark fruit, old leather, brown sugar, hint of sweat socks. Taste: crème brulee, with notes of toasted oat bread, roasted nuts, raisin cookies, cherries, and a hint of chocolate.  Finish: long, sweet nutty character with a hint of toast and stone fruits.   Notes: 	Nutty, toasty ,sweet and drinkable.  Whats not to like?
Brown with a slightly brown head.Tastes malty with a bit chocolate and toffee and a full body. Definetly recommendable but not outstanding.
Bottle. Elegantly smooth and sweet. Notes of toffee, chocolate and a touch of smoke. A little short in taste, maybe a little watery. On the other hand quite drinkable.
Nice traditional German dunkel. Smooth and full bodied. Easy drinking beer that and i will look for more styles of theirs.
Dark-red colour, bit oily liquid. Aroma of caramel and herbs. Hops with bitterness and malts with sweet notes in the taste. A very good dunkel easily drinkable but still a special one.

5l bulihordó, Sörspecialista, Budapest. Inkább vörös, mintsem barna színű ez a dunkel, fény felé tartva pedig csillog, akár egy ékszer. Közepes méretű és közepesen kitartó, enyhén krémes bézs színű habot fejleszt. Illata karamellás, aszalt gyümölcsös és enyhén pörkölt malátás, illetve van egy fűszeres, jó tanninos vörösborra emlékeztető aromája is. Íze inkább édeskés, kissé csípős, és a vörösboros jelleg erősen érződik, mintha egy jóféle barnával lenne összeöntve egy tüzes bor, de az érkező komlós keserűség azért helyesen az előbbi felé húzza. Édeskés, kellemesen szénsavas és kissé olajos, de csak közepesen testes, igazán finom német barna sör, amit azért illik komolyan venni, mégis egészen könnyen csúszik.

0.5l bottle from Fenaknoken, Oslo. The Barok has a deep deep ruby-red body with a big creamy and lasting light tanned head. Aroma is thin and low, but there are some notes of dark malts, burned caramel and some wet cardboard. Average to soft carbonation, sticky to oily texture and medium-bodied. Tastes light burned, dark malts, really low on the bitterness and it ends light sticky and watery. Drinkable as a dunkel, and got more and more flavorful as it got some temperature. Quite OK.
Pour is a dark brown with a average tan head. Aroma is caramel malts with some dark fruits. Flavor is a bit weaker but some dark malts come out and not much else. Finish is watery and unremarkable.

Bottle. Moderately dark brown with a big and rocky head. Aroma is sweetish, bready-malty, reminding of a black pumpernikel bread. Quite a lot of raisins, some caramel and vinous elements, and even some vanilla. Taste is moderately toasted malt, pumpernikel and raisins. Slighty sweet and also only slightly bitterish, plus some subtle grassy hops in the aftertaste. A classic dunkel worthy of its pioneer status.

Clear chestnut brown with a small baige head. Quite delicious toffee aroma with dry chocolate and grain. Nice clean flavor, sweet toffee and a light mainly roasted bitterness with a medium carbonateion.

Pours a dark brown color with a two finger head.  Plenty of nutty, toffee, and bread forward malts.  A bit of chocolate, dark fruits, and a light lager yeast aroma.  Toasted bread, toffee, and a hint of caramel.  A little bit of nuttiness and cocoa powder.  Light lager yeast and a very subtle hop flavor.  Light to medium in body with a medium level of carbonation.

Bottle @ Home. Pours clear ebony with a creamy offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, sweet milk chocolate. Taste is malt, caramel, chocolate, light fruit, grassy hops. Creamy mouthfeel, medium body, soft carbonation. Nice brew, 180611

Chevy Chase Wine and Liquors, DC 500ml ($4ish): Pours a really pretty reddish brown with a nice beige head. Aroma of caramel malts and a hint of hops. Beer is on the light side of things in terms of body, but maintains a really full flavor. Slight sweetness in the finish and lingers into a pleasant aftertaste. Hops are subdued, but present enough to add character. There is also some toffee and some dark fruit-like flavors going on there. This is not the most complex beer, but it is done pretty much entirely correctly. Could easily drink this in summer, spring, or winter.

Bottle, thanks to Quack-Duck. Brown color with large beige head. Aroma, fruit, caramel. Taste, caramel, red fruits and cola. sweet finish. When I saw, mostly high ratings, I thought, beer will be better.

Intensiver röstmalziger Geruch, mitteldunkle Farbe. Es schmeckt auch malzig, allerdings überschattet von einem wässrgen Beigeschmack. Kein tolles Bier. 	 
Test vom 30.9.2005, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 9,6,7,7,10,6 - 6,80

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2011 Bottle. Pours the color of cola with a medium, beige head. Aroma is soapy hops, roasted malts, coffee. Taste is coffee, roasted, rye bready malts that comes together nicely with the grassy hops in the finish.

Deep reddish brown pour that loses its head quickly. Scent of caramel apples and some sterility. Other deep dark fruits. Flavor of dark fruits and some spicyness. Candied plums and apricot maybe. Some raisin and cocoa. A heavy-medium mouthfeel. Not as good as their classic Asam Bock, but pretty good in its own right.

Bottle. A rich deep red-brown hue. Nice full and well lasting light tan head, lacing retained. Inviting aroma full of malt, caramel and a touch of coffee; overall sweet but not over-cloying. Tast, omnomnomnom. Big whack of rich malt with some caramel, fresh balanced bitterness to offset. Long balance sweet/bitter finish which clings to the corners of the mouth. Lively and soft on palate without being over-fizzed, slight oily mouthfeel. Overall: a new favourite of mine now. Reasonably priced for an import, and i thoroughly enjoy the 500 ml bottle.
From the 5 liter minikeg. It is a smooth, lighter carbonated, rich and chocolatey dunkel that is pretty tasty on a hot summer day.

500 ml bottle at the first counterterrorism civil-military relations beer tasting in Garmisch, Germany.  Clear brown, with yeast at the end of the bottle pour.  Aroma of burnt butterscotch, taste of over-roasted peanuts.  More flavorful than your average dunkel.

pours a deep dark caramel color with a nice head that dissipates quickly. aroma is typical german dark roasted malts. caramel roasted malts and some creaminess in the taste. very smooth and highly enjoyable. definately one of the better german dunkels.

Bottle shared at jcwattsruggers. Poured a chestnut brown body of medium density with a small foamy beige head. Aroma is sweet, nutts, syrup, roasty and choclate syrup. Flavor is the same as the aroma. Thiner bodied with light carbonation. Overall nice but needs a touch more carbonation.

Clear medium brown pour, white head.  Pleasant roasty, grainy, malty nose.  Also tastes grainy and roasty with a caramelly and chocolate hints, finishes with a very mild bitterness.  Light bodied.  Not exactly an exciting or complex beer, but impressively clean and unflawed with a subtle balance to it.
Bottle at Johns tasting. Pours dark brown. White head. Nose and taste of roasted barley, sweet and black malts, grain and dark wheat. Medium body. Solid.

Golden brown colour, with a light brown long lasting head. A subtle and sweet malty aroma.Taste is medium sweet, light caramel. Medium body. I perfectly understand the "well balanced" part of the commercial description.
[50 cl bottle, Ultra, Bryn, Oslo]
Bottle. Drank this one on a trip to Chicago. Deep brown with amber highlights. Nice head, some lace. Love the chocolate, coffee toasty nut flavor. Good stuff.

Bottle. Dark red/brown clear with a tanned head. Smells of caramell and roasted malts. Taste is round and smooth with caramell sweetness and malt sweetness. Some bitterness in the finish, but not any dryness.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2013 Re-rated. Dark brown colour with a short lived off-white head. Aroma is very malty with notes of caramel, bread and toffee. The taste is malty, lightly roasted with caramel and toffee. A little watery. Not bad.

Bottle 50cl. A clear brown beer with good head. Smell is caramel like and toasted. Aroma is medium sweet, very malted, toasted, some chocolate hints, finish is slightly bitter and metallic. Good body with barley sugar, bread and grassy notes.

Dark reddish brown beer with large cream-white head. Malty nose, dry grains and some sweet syrupy bread. Aika hint of dark dried fruits and mildly  grassy hops. Sweetish malty flavor, finishes drier with gentle roastedness and and touch offset chocolate. Light bitterness in the finish. Medium body, low carbonation and velvety texture. Really nice dunkel it is.

large rocky fizzy offwhite head. excellent lacing. mostly diminishihg. translucent thin brown body. aroma: dark bread, heavy roasted malt, mild coffee. if: light sweet bitter. ff: light sweet acidic bitter; average duration. palate: light medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, metallic finish.suaves notas chocolate e malte no paladar, R$ 11

Nota: 8 skol
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2016 Nice dunkel. Malty flavors a little caramel but not too much. Not over complex but still flavorful. Serving: Bottle

chestnut brown body, mostly clear, small off-white head, little retention.  nose basically smells like sparged wort (bran muffin, cookie dough and starchy toast character of caramel, munich, other dark and semi-dark malts) and bread dough (yeast). thin body, mild flavor of graham crackers and dough, brown sugar, semi-bitter nuts and toffee.  fairly simple.
Clear, dark red brown. Some light brown, frothy head. Aroma of caramel, coffee, bread and roasted malts. Flavour is roasted malts, barley and caramel.

500ml bottle.  Pours a deep chestnut brown with a beige head that lingers.  Sweet malty aroma, with nuttiness and toffee.  Flavor is sweet caramel malt, toffee, brown sugar, nuts, and toast. Medium bodied with a smooth and slick mouthfeel.

Bottled. Very dark amber coloration with a tan head that fade out quickly. A very poor lace keeping. Aroma is weak with notes of roasted malt and bread, the flavor is better the roasted malt shows up stronger than in the aroma, also some caramel and a ending sweet touch. mouthfeel is quite dry. I liked.
Sehr gutes Bier, "Bierkrug" hat es mir zum probieren gegeben, sehr guter Geschmack. Malzig, nicht zu würzig und sehr lecker. Kann ich nur weiterempfehlen für jeden!

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2012 Bottle @ home. Pours a brown body with a big foamy, light brown head. Nutty, delicious, sweet dark malty lager nose. Creamy mouth feel. Delicious, nutty, rich, toasty dark malty, light toffee flavor. Quite possibly my favorite Dunkel. Spectacular!

Picked this up at Hi-Times in Costa Mesa, always a solid selection. Poured a deep brown , somewhat chunky head. Big malts on the nose, ton of sweet caramel. Taste was very smooth, very drinkable with a strong malt finish, good stuff.

500ml bottle. Pours a clear dark red-brown, with a large beige head, excellent retention and reasonable lacing. The nose is a little weak, but there are some coffee and herb notes. Herbal and peppery hops introduce it, moving into a dark-roasted coffee mid-section and a slightly sweeter finish. A nice dunkel.

draught at the Local Taphouse Oktoberfest. one of the nicer beers of the day, pours a dark clear amber. chocolate and caramel aromas, with the main flavours being a toasted malt and a slight fruitiness.
Bottle. Almost a roasted nut aroma, but sweet. Tastes of roasted malts, mild chocolate, butterscotch and breads. Aftertaste lingers on the back of the tongue - again, roast flavor. Nice.

Light brown looks, with a slight beige head. Malt, roasty caramel aroma, some dough also. Medium sweetness balanced with some malty taste but then turns a bit watery, its a shame. Light/medium body with soft carbonation, soft sweet and bitter after taste.
Cerveja que não me surpreendeu. Espuma de boa formação, marron. Coloração vinho. Cheiro de cereais maltado - madeira. Frisante. Caramelo amargo, malte presente.

500 ml bottle @ home. Rated @ 15.7.2009.
Pours a clear light brown colour with a rich off-white head. The aroma is roasted malts, bread and fruits. Medium sweet flavour of caramel malts, spices and mild hops. Medium bodied, watery mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Nice dunkel.

bottle. Very nice warm nutbrown color with a small tan head. Sweet nose. Lightly spicey, sweet aroma with bread tones. Flavour is sweet with malts. Slightly spicey and malty finish with subdued bitterness and light watery tone. Starts perfect but finish could be more bitter with heavier at the finish.

Bottle: Pours a Murky Brown Color, and smells like first malt, with some funkiness. Flavors are more impressive, with a certain level of sweetness and roasted malt on the finish. I wasnt looking forward to this brew but was pleasantly surprised. Not a dunkel fan at all, but this was by far my favorite -

On tap at Haus Staudt, 0.5 liters served in a big ol stein.  Pours a translucent medium brown color with a nice off-white head that leaves thick foam and excellent lacing.  Sweet malty aroma, fairly nutty and toffeeish.  Smells pretty good.  Flavor is great.  Sweet caramel malt, toffee, brown sugar, nuts, and toast.  Medium-full bodied for the style with a smooth and slick mouthfeel.  Great, great dunkel overall.  Really surprising.  A beer even worthy of "Barock" Obama (although I hear the prez prefers Bud Light, that sellout).

Pours clear deep red amber with huge tanned head leving some lacing. Caramel, chocolate, dark bread and spicy aroma. Fresh, malty with hints of hops and fruits flavor. Tart, acidy and a bit sweet on palate. Finishes with malty hoppy aftertaste.
This is a solid Dunkel whose best feature is its silky palate.  The flavors are well-melded, perhaps enough to make them something less than distinguished.  Good old school Dunkel flavor.
bottle, the color of weak coffee with 1/2" tan foam, aroma of cola, figs and prunes, woody, flavors are malty, dusty pecan shell, fruity, dry finish

50cl bottle. Poured red/brown color with a nice fluffy beige head. FAroma is coffee and caramel. Flavour is nice sweet roasted malty, coffee and caramel. Just very well balanced, not oversweet as many dunkels tend to be. One of the better dunkels I have tried.

Poured into an old traditional German stein.  Lots of foam, dark brown pour.  Malt smooth with a slight roasted grain, earthy flavor.  Medium pallet feel with light carbonation.  Some dry sweetness towards the finish.  Good drinker.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Chestnut brown pour with a red sheen. Beige head. Aromas of dark roast coffee, malts, chocolate, smoke, toffee. Flavours of chocolate, caramel. coffee, sweet spices, brown sugar. Malt laden mouthfeel. Dry, malty and gently hoppy finish. Very pleasant.
Dark red brown body and tan head. Sweet and creamy caramel, chocolate and some floral hops. Roasted caramel, creamy, hints of brown sugar flavor. A very good dunkel to drink. Sweet and enjoyable.

Bottle 50 cl from Terra Vinea in Morteau (F). Mahogany brown with sticky beige foam and low crackling. Scent of malt, caramel, touches of licirice, vanilla, cake and chocolate. Malted mouth of cookies, brown sugar, therefore rather round with low bitterness. Finish mellow, smoky and hoppy.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt. Pours a nice deep golden brown color. Aromas of rich dark malts, chocolate, fruit. Flavor is rich with a lot of flavors light chocolate, dark fruit, smoke, coffee.

500ml from Capital market, Salem.
Nice dark brown beer with a gorgeous frothy,tan head.
very bready malt aromas,..bread and oat cereal. Like it.
Smooth milk chocolate and coffee with boiled milk flavours.Slight hints of bitterness in the end.
Very smooth ..silky smooth palate.
Overall i really liked this soft, malt driven beer.

0.5 l bottle.
Dark brown colour with a beige creamy head, carbonations soft.
Sweet, roasty and yeasty smell, tastes sweetsour, flavours of coffee and caramell.
Aromas roasty, yeasty and of citrus hops.
The finish is pleasantly coffeebitter, hoppy and dry.
Medium bodied, nice dunkel one.

Bottle 500ml. Pours red-brownish color with medium beige head. Low to medium carbonation and medium body. Taste is very malty, sweet, and a bit smokey. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. Pretty much no bitterness here. Very well balanced, one of the best Dunkels Ive had.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2012 Red brown. Huge beige head. High bead. Aroma of singed malt and caramel. Light complex toffee sweetness with some smoke. Lovely balanced drop. [3.6]Bottle, 11C. Clear reddish brown with a large, lasting beige head. Caramel, bread, some burnt/ smoky notes. Rich but easy drinking with lovely balancing bitterness. Dry finish. Quite a bit of smoke at the end. Miles ahead of anything like it Ive tried.
Bottle. Large tan head over a clear red brown body. Aroma and taste of caramel, brown sugar with spicey floral elements in a balanced finish. Medium bodied.

Draught at Stockholm beer and whiskey festival. 
The aroma is dominated by burnt malt and caramell. The taste is likevise with a low bitterness. No sweetness and big drinkabillity.

Appearance: Clear brown color with garnet highlight. Small bubbles. Small tan head with poor retention.

Aroma: Dark grainy purity, cocoa-powder, milk chocolate with almost rye-bread quality.

Flavor: Restrained milk-chocolaty, caramel sweetness up-front. Some black-forest cake-like fruity, sweet character at the medium. Subtle, balanced spicy hop at the end.

Mouthfeel/Palate: Just as u would expect from a Dunkel. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Decent yeasty background.

Overall Impression: I like this kind of "ruby" Dunkels. Balanced and sweet Dunkel with light hop level and not cloying at all. Very pure malty background.

Szép mély rubinvörös színe van a tetején egy bézs színű közepes méretű,gyorsan apadó habbal.Illata hasonló egy mazsolás-mogyorós tejcsokoládéhoz és érezni a malátát is benne.Íze édeskésen,kakaósan és aszalt szilvásan kezdődik,ami átmegy egy  enyhén erdei gyümölcsösen fanyar ízbe,ami mögött érezni a komló aromáját is.Teste enyhén vizes és közepesen szénsavas az ital.Utóíze pörkölt magvas és meggy bonbonos,kitölti a szája és hosszan tartót.Szép dunkel és könnyen fogyasztható,de nem érhet fel az Assam  nevű bátyjához.
Bottle from Cracked Kettle. Dark brown body with sticky head. Nose of malts and caramel. Taste is quite watery, of malts. Then gets sweeter towards the end and spicier. Nice dunkel.

Bottle. Ruddy, clear mahogany with a one finger, disappearing tan head. Sweet, buttery, toffee nose with some toasted malt notes - quite subtle.  Creamy sweet malt flavours. Bready, nutty tones, a bit buttery with some good toasty bitterness. Not bad but a touch slight in terms of body. Fair carbonation gives it a dryness on the palate.

1/2 Liter.  Pours a amber body with an off white head.  Dark fruit, raisins, dates, some raw sugar tones.  Malty, some roast and nuts.  A bit light and thin with some bread y notes.  Nice easy drinking ale.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2010 Cofee-like, dark brown color with decent head; aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate; medium body, slightly rough (in a good sense) moutheel; flavor adapting the nose endind up in dry, slightly bitter finish.

Bottle. Dark amber colour with a small off-white head. Malty aroma with notes of rye. The flavour is slightly sweet and malty with notes of rye and some herbs. Medium-bodied, slightly bitter aftertaste.

Bottle from K-citymarket Sello, Espoo. Malty and chocolatey aroma. Reddish brown beer with white lace. Tastes sweetly malty and a bit nutty and chocolatey. Quite nice body for only 4,7% beer and overall a good beer in this ABV. Big brother Asam Bock is one of my favourites.

500 ML bottle in Germany. Dark brown nice partly see through color. Light brown head. Aroma is hard to pinpoint but a fastastic aroma, wonderful. A high class beer. Claims the oldest Dunkel of the world, might be, but it is one of the best for sure. The standard others are set.  A wonderful flavor of many tastes. Again hard to say them all. I like this better than their Bock.

Good brew! Served with a full foamy, frothy light tan head and a little lace. Head settled down to a thin cover shortly. Color is a lovely, clear, deep, dark amber. Aroma is malty and a bit roasty with a hint of burnt sugar. Flavor is quite nice with the above nose qualities plus a bit of hop. Good carbonation tho the liquid seems just a tad thin. Very nice finish. Definitely a session beer.

Bottled 500ml. -from beerangel.de shared with Doggythedog. 
Reddish/brown (cola) coloured, medium sized beige head, dry nutty caramel nose. Sweet malty (light roasted also), milk chocolate and some herbs with notes of chestnut and hops in the finish. Drinkable but pretty average dunkel.

On tap at the Malt House: Poured a dark mahogany, fairly clear, nice sized head with decent retention. Very suprised how bright and light it was for a dunkel. Quite a bit of caramel malt. A little toasty as well. Finishes rich and smooth.

Bottle from beerangel.de, shared with ogivlado Poured a dark, slightly brownish red with a small-medium lovely thick off white head that went away relatively fast. Sweet grainy malt aroma, roasty and coffeeish but kinda akin to dog food... ugh. People seem to enjoy this kind of aroma looking at this and Asam Bock but its a bit off putting for me... The taste is malty again, dominated by a similar roasty coffeeish maltiness that sometimes ventures into dog food territory but not nearly as much as the doppelbock did. Light herbal, lightly acidic hop aftertaste. Didnt like it at first but it grew on me later on. Its a solid dunkel and I can respect it.
Clear dark reddish-brown pour with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, sweetness. Roasted malt, little nutty, sweetness, dry finish. Goes down easy. A good beer for under $2.50. Lacing minimal.

A Mes rate. Bottle from some random offy, drunk in the most random venue while watching my friend Jamie play a gig. Superb environment to squeeze a rate in.Utterly superb rich smoky malt aroma. Cakes and biscuits abound. REALLY sniffable. The flavour is almost as impressive. Its held back just a little by the aggressive carbonation but it still good. Good complex layers or tobacco and leather with more rich malt sitting quietly in the background. Some coffee and chocolate in the finish round it off really well. I dont know much about this brewery but what I know is great. German beers that manage to break out of the very standard mold that others seem so restricted by. Excellent.
A big malty beer.  Now were talking!  This is a great beer because it tastes like a beer should taste: beer.

500ml bottle.  Pours a darker but clear red dark brown with a whipped frothy light tan head.  Aroma of malt dust and sweet raisin bread.  Classic Weltenburger completeness, dry, touch roast, some bitterness at first, hint of acidity, subtle delicately roasted nuts, touch ashy, just the perfect hint of rich toffee/burnt sugar, finishing lightly bready, touch of raisin, exceptionally clean.   Medium/light bodied, milky sensation, seemingly watery, light larger fizzy carbonation.  A very very good dunkel.  Easy drinking and very well balanced.

Pours a clear dark amber, with a head that continues to grow long after the initial pour - aroma of toffee, hazelnut, roasted malts, dark bread - clean, smooth, medium-bodied - an initial toffee-ish sweetness is quickly replaced but a more burnt/caramelized sweetness, roasted nuts, moderate bitterness through the middle - some light raisin and date character on the back end - lingering dry cocoa flavor in the finish - quite a tasty dunkel.
Pours red brown with large long lasting and nicely lacing off-white head. Toasty milk chocolate and toffee in aroma. Caramell and burnt sugar in flavor with a nice lingering malty bitter aftertaste.
Sampled in Fussen. A pretty good brew. Drank nicely with a good amount of flavor. One of the better dunkels I have had. Pours dark with medium head. Goes down very smooth.

500 ml. bottle. Reddish brown colour, wirh a brownish head that doesnt last too long. Earthy aroma of caramel and dark fruits, with hints of chocolate. Rough but sweet flavor, taste is earthy, caramel, chocolate, raisins and fruits. This is one you can try again more than once.
Bottle. Pours brown with a large white head. Roasted malt, caramel, fruit and sugar. Smooth and bitter finish. Its a nice dunkel.
Deep copper colour with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of toffee, bread and a hint of chocolate. Dry and malty flavour with lingering milk chocolate.

Poured this guys up and the smell was lovely.Had a nice husky smell. Dense but short lived tan head. Had a lovely taste. Thick roasty chocolate, sweet and malty. Its not an Ayinger but it was pretty stinking close in my mouth even with the differences. I like this one alot.

Bottle; pours a dark, reddish brown color with a small to medium, short lasting head.  Aroma was pretty nice with caramel and dark fruit; some nuts and bread too.  Flavor wasnt as good as the aroma, but still it was solid.  A lot of bread, with some fruit, caramel and cocoa.  Palate came off a little rough and harsh.
30 cl draft. Clear amber colour with off-white head. Nothing to exciting about it.

Bottle. Low white and quickly disappearing head. Clear dark red brown body. Roasted barley malt aroma with caramel. Pretty sweet. Heavily carbonated barley malt cocoa caramel honey flavor. Long sweet aftertaste.

Bottle. The aroma is malty and light sweet, very soft touch of alcohol. The head is medium large, beige and foamy-creamy with a normal duration. The body is clear and red. Clear garnet. Light beige head quickly settles and disperses. Iron, molasses and grapey aromas preside over mere hints of caramelized malt and dark bread. Prickly effervescence tickles the palate. Opens with an irony twang which eventually succumbs to a bittersweet chocolate- and hazelnut-tinged malt blend. Candied pecan sweetness and barklike astringency trail closely behind. While poorly attenuated, theres quite a bit of airiness which keeps the flabby fruitiness at bay. That said, the malt is heavily obscured by the weighty residuals. Plummy fruitiness and notes of red licorice are omnipresent as the malt begins to take on a creamed coffee accent toward the finish. Dunkel lager must be clean, delicate and focused (bottle conditioned and unfiltered would also be welcomed), and while this is fairly delicate, the insistent fruitiness, prickly carbonation and irony acid mar a potentially pleasurable experience.

Optimistic (?) Bottle date of March 2009; Sampled December 2007
Pours with a frothy, initially three-finger thick, amber tinged, tan colored head that sit on top of a blackened, concentrated brown colored brew that shows a brilliantly clear, concentrated garnet color when held up to the light.  Rich malt aromatics greet my nose upon my first smell of the aroma.  Sweet, concentrated / caramelized malt notes, a hint of molasses, touches of chocolate, a substantial toasted note along with hints of lightly burnt toast and browned, crushed soda crackers.  The rich malt aromatics almost take on a butterscotch like note as the beer warms up.

Quite light feeling up front, but it picks up some light heft towards the middle and finish.  Still this is a very quaffable brew.  Malt focused with darker grain flavors of caramelized malt sugar, sweet malt, touches of toasted / almost roasted malt and a really pronounced, browned, soda cracker note in the finish.  The finish has a light bitterness that couples with an almost raisin like malt sweetness and a slightly dusty malt character.  As the beer warms it picks up a slight herbal note that couples with the light hop bitterness in the finish.

This should really appeal to the malt lovers out there, despite being relatively low in alcohol it has a full, rich, textured malt character to it.  Plus it is very light and easy drinking.

Very enjoyable beer, especially served in the dimpled mug. Not overly strong, but a nice dark fruits flavour is apparent

Pours a cloudy red-brown. Head is large and khaki. Aroma is toffee, caramel, spiced pit fruits and lightly of smoke/savory stew. Texture is medium. Flavor is pit fruit malt, coffee, chocolate, toffee, caramel, beef stock, peat and smoke. Very complex, but never heavy, oily or strong. Superbly balanced and "just right". About halfway through the bottle I broke out crackers and smoked gouda. Not typical for me to eat with my beer. But I can just imagine being in Germany, pounding these with hamburgers, steaks and bbq chicken every meal. Thatd be awesome.

Bottle (from bitter virtue). Toffee and malt with dried fruit and nuts. Despite the sweet flavours it doesnt drink quite as sweetly as I would have imagined. Light roasty bitterness helps round it off. Quite nice.

Rated 2005-04-30. Dark brown and red in color, pretty thick beige head which lowers pretty fast, tiny lace. Aroma is bit roasted, coffee, dark chocolate, caramelly and sweet with notes of nut. Medium bodied. Roasted, coffee-like, chocolaty, bit sweet and creamy flavor with notes of rye. Long and bit smoky finish. Very good and complex dunkel.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is fruit, malt, caramel. Flavour is fruit, malt, caramel, hop. Ok beer.

Bottled. Pours a clear, deep copper with a beige head. Malty, a bit roasted aroma. Malty and grainy flavor. Medium body. Malt, caramel and some hops in the finish. Definately not bad, but maybe a bit on the malty side, yet it could use some more body, flavor and alcohol. (070404)
Bottle at Brew Wharf at London Bridge, dark brown with a large foamy tan head. A nutty malt aroma with a hop sweetness. Very malty flavour and an effervescent light palate. I had higher expectations.
Spanish import BB 02/03/07. Deep ruby pour with rocky cream suds. Sweet, darkly fruity snout. Figs and raisins. Roasted malt and licorice bitterness. A lick of Marmite. Not bad.
Looks clear and dark brown in the glass. Wide malty aroma with roastedness, also slightly sweet. Quite long aftertaste.

Big active head early but settles quickly. Colour is a very clear light chocolate brown. Nose is an interesting and very balanced mix of roasts and chocolate. Good penetration. Less depth in the flavours when compared to the indications provided by the bouquet. Fizz palate dominates a little early, making the flavours hard to shine, although nutty coffee roast and hints of chocolate emerge in the middle and back palate. Shows plenty of balance. Very textbook and true to the genre.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a longlasting off-white head. Malty bready caramel aroma. Sweet malty bready and slightly grainy flavor with hints of caramel. Sweet malty finish with some hints of caramel in the aftertaste.
Firm malty with a surprisly dry finish. Page 490 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide

500ml bottle from Trafalgar Wines, Brighton.  Deep reddy/russet colour with lasting thin beige head.  Toffee, toasty aroma. Some butter.  Goodish buttery toffee flavour, just a little lacking in body in the mouth.  Good crisp finish.  Buttery lime on the end.  Interesting dunkel.  Needs more fullness though, more deep malt.  Tasty though.

Definately one of the best dunkels I ever have tasted. Aroma of nutty sweetmalted ingredients. Flavor is fullbodied in the dunkelway and very malty, smooth, some weak smoke and indeed, for the style, a complex beer. Ill buy it again!

Nut brown with fine lasting white head. Malty nose with notes of dark fruits & caramel. Lively carbonation. Hops are hard to trace.  Bread & nut notes. Rather fresh.  Filling body with a good  lasting finish.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2007 Bottle. Big lasting tan head over a crystal clear amber body. Good lacing. Not so evident, but alluring aromas of nutty, sweet toasted malts. Taste is much the same; malts, nuts, with  slight toasted and caramelish flavors. No hops detected. Llight-bodied for the style. Rather thin palate. Short, watery finish.

Poured a translucent brown-red color, nice off-white head, pretty solid lacing all the way down. The aroma was caramel and very light roasted notes. The flavor was caramel, bready, nuts, light chocolate notes, and a very light smoke/roast undertone. The mouthfeel was full, yet finishes dry, very well attenuated and balanced against a nice malt base. For a style thats never impressed me, this beer was fantastic, perhaps the best dunkel Ive ever had. Good stuff, solid numbers for its excellency in style!

Pours to a dark brown with just a hint of ruby red, medium of-white head dissipates very quickly, and leaves little lacing. Aroma is a pleasnt mixture of roasted nuts and dark fruit with malty sweet undertones. Taste is along the same lines, nutty and sweet with a hint of fruit. Body is a little on the thin side, which accounts for a weak mouthfeel and short finish that is a little on the watery side, but still enjoyable.

Sampled from a 16.9 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark brown color with ruby highlights and a large tan head. The aroma was sour vegetal malts and molasses. The flavor was sour and sweet vegetal malts with a long tangy finish. Too much like V8 for me to really enjoy.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2010 Light brown, a little muddy, with a fast dissapearing head. The aroma is quite powerful, but I cant really describe it. It has of course malts, but also a weird grassy, earthy tone. The flavor has chocolate, malts, the earthy tone, and then a slight bitter finish. Dry beer, with medium body. It has some schwarzbier elements I think, but it suits it fine. A very fine brew, but I would prefer Rebel Cerný to this one.

Has a nice malty aroma, rich with burnt sugar and molasses. A bit brothy, though, with Tootsie Roll and carbonic gassiness. Light bitter grassy hops. Dark brown clear with reddish tint. Rocky light tan head with some lacing. Medium-light watery body with heavy carbonation. Malty start with rich notes of molasses and toffee, brown sugar and some coffee. Dusty grain and hay. Finish is somewhat bitter but more of a dry nutty character. After is nutty and dry with tangy molasses notes. Not really complex but a decent dunkel.
Bottle. Clear amber/brown with a nice creamy off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and roasted nuts. Flavour: sweet, roasted malt, bit of chocolate. Slightly smoked.

15-Dec-06	500ml bottle in Munich.	Rich, carmelly& malty aroma.  Molasses, chocolate and roast notes. .. .	Dark brown, cola like. ..Tan head that lasts and laces quite nicely. .	Smooth, malty, nutty with chocolate & toasty flavors.  Some minor bitterness. ..	Smooth, light med body,  med carbonation.. ..	A very tasty & smooth dark beer.  Would love to have more of this one - very smooth and complex.  Great stuff. ..
Hop malt aroma with stone fruit. Clear brown colour with foamy head. Smooth malt flavour with sluight sweet fruit aftertaste. Smooth palate.
Draught at Byens Kro. Unclear dark brown - light brown head. Wheat, fruity, berries, bread, yeast, dried fruits, a bit boring.

Botlle 0.5 L

Clear ruby amber brown , huge handsome fine tan top. Handsome dunkel that is . Good lacing. 4+

Refreshing , clean feel , think meadow, think freshly harvested grain and stack of drying hops ,think at end sugar candy blanket.

Clean malty body , slightly spritzy , light woody touches. Very clean work , no off notes. Lighter dunkel than most that is more visible as you drink .
Bottle. Ruby caramel beer with a nice off-white head. Caramel aroma with some dark malts. Mineral, caramel flavor. Lighter bodied. Minerals linger and are too strong.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a medium head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, burned malt and plums.
Deep red color with no head.  Burnt grain aroma.  Odd, almost sour, maple flavor.  Kind of a granola-ish finish.

From a 500 ml. euro bottle with a freshness date on the back label.

Poured a ruby hued amber with a small foamy pale tan head that settled into a fine bubbly lacing, minimal amount of laced sticking.

Aromas of cocoa, caramel, minerals, a subtle nuttiness and a tiny bit herbal.

Good moderate carbonation and a softly malty crisp, smooth light-medium bodied mouthfeel.

Pleasant tasting, lightly, lightly roasted malts, cocoa, a coffee caramel, a buried nuttiness, a mineral flavor shows up just after the middle of the taste, a herbal hop flavor, not very potent, and a malty finish with some metallic edges.

Not a great German dunkel, wouldnt be one of first five choices if I was in a bar or restaurant, but passable drinkability.

Bottle. Aroma of sweet malt and caramel. These are suplemented with some coffee and hops in the flavor. Rather creamy on the palate and finishes off with a nice taste of moderate sweetness and burnt malt. Really a well made Dunkel.

Pours dark but not opaque in my steeler stein.  Smell of fresh beer, what else?  Initial taste of perhaps a little hops but that only lasts a second.  Flavor moves on to a refreshing dark beer sensation. No bitterness on the finish.  Very drinkable. Best dunkle Ive tasted.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Deep reddish brown with a moderate tan foamy head, no lacing. Yeasty and caramel aroma.  Taste is malty-sweet, fruity, a little thin/watery and hoppy-bitter. Decent Dunkel indeed.
Bottled: Poured a medium brown with red highlights. Medium head. Malty aroma with hints of plums. Malty flavours dominate as expected but its pretty well balanced. This is a good workman like beer.
From 500 mL bottle.  Light mahogany pour with tan head.  Nose is rich caramel malt, although not that strong.  Flavor follows with a light bitter finish and medium body.

Bottle, about 1 week after its due date. Wonderful colour; deep-deep amber. Unfortunately not too much foam at fridge temperature (bad me). Lively aroma of dark malt, plum, raisins and some metal. Could be that the bottle is old, but theres a nasty taste in this. Something sticks out, nettles or rubber or vinegar... Other than that, the taste is full and rich of plum, alcohol and vinegar.
Clear, amber beer. Beide head. Lasting and lacing. Has a nice malty, slightly burnt aroma. Flavor is malty too, perhaps a bit salty. Finish is bitter.

(Draught at Man in the Moon, Stockholm) Colour is dark ruby with a beige, frothy, disappearing, head. Nose is malty with notes of chocolate and dark fruit (cherries?). Taste is malty with chocolate, nuts and dark fruit. Some malty sweetness, but still fairly dry. Medium body. Balanced bitterness with some hops in the finish. Good beer, but lacking something extra.
Bottle: Dark brown color with a nice Head. Big malty aroma with hints of dark fruit. Flavor is a malty and a little thin. Not something that envokes a strong reaction but rather refreshing.

Bottle. Mahogany with a small frothy tan head. Nose is bready with sweet malts, soft cocoa, and light grains. Some hints of grassiness as well. Taste is malt and caramel with some grass notes and strong bready flavors. Body is creamy and smooth with a medium overall feel. Finishes with more caramel, grains, bread and light spicy hops. Nice!

Poured a fairly true brown with a thick head that hung around for a little while, then faded to a thin layer. Aroma of raisins, molasses and a hop/yeast thing that had me thinking of some pommy ales. Not a bad balance in the flavour initially, but it gets a little sweet after a while, with the malt dominant and the hops nowhere to be seen (or tasted). A bit soda-like and a somewhat oily mouthfeel, the aftertaste is quite bready and satisfying. A decent, if not challenging, beer.

Bottle: Mahogany ruby color, light head and light lacing. Nose of raisin, plum, sweet wort and clean yeast and hops. The flavor is balanced, decent body and a nice rye toasty dark bread quality. The finish is nicely balanced with some sweetness. Good dark toffee and medium grain malts.

Bottle Pours a dark chestnut brown witha medium tan head and thin sticky lacing.  Aroma was very nice sweet woody and carmely malt ensemble. Flavor I thought was lacking much of anything.  Slightly roasted and dark but papery and  slightly astringent.  Dissapouinting after the big tease in the aroma.  Feel was a bit thin and the carbonation was fairly soft. Thanks Buch Dich for this one.
Bottle pours out a very nice Dark amber color topped a creamy tan head. Malty and sweet with some roast on it as well. Thanks Bück Dich
Mahogany brown beer with whitebrown and long lasting head. Aroma malt. Taste much malt.
tap. dark amber golden color. malty and soapy. sweet and grainy. bit nutty.
[50cl can] Brown body, good beige head. Coffee and roasted grain aroma. Sweet malty caramel taste. Drinkable, light to medium-bodied,  rather monodimensional. Not too interesting.

Very dark brown color with a medium sized tan head. Great lacing. Big malty aroma with hints of dark fruit. Flavor is a malty and a little thin. Not something that envokes a strong reaction but rather refreshing.
On tap. Brownish amber coloured with a medium sized off-white head. Malty and sweet with hints of caramel and bread. A very weak hint of nuts.
500ml Bottle. Cyprus @ All about beer. Beautiful brown color, medium off-white head. Roasted malt aroma. Full body, nice bitterness and great aftertaste. Would drink again anytime.

Aroma: light matl with a hint of carbon. Appearance: browny amber wtih a lightly off white strong head that leaves sheet lacing. Flavour: matly with a hint of carbon and some bitterness/vitamin C. Palate: thin to medium mouthfeel, lightly carbonated. Leaves some floral notes in the finish.

Bottle thanks to Mane!, I prefer the dunkelweissens to just a dunkle. Its a porter watered down. The apperance is very nice with a clear dark cherry body and an off white head. Nose and flavors of caramel and roasted malts, a tad salty and vinegary. Very watery and light. Could have used some more gravity to my likings.

I gotta admit.. when these get poured into their official glass, I pour as violently as possible. Now that thats out of the way... mahogony body with a large head. Aroma is caramel, dark bread, hints of nuts. Flavor though was a turn off. The bottle might have been too old, Im not sure. It made the trip from Germany to California to NY...
Bottle. Creamy off-white good fully lasting head. Beatifull dark redbrown colour. Nice malty roasted aroma. Thin sweet flavor, light bitter finish. Watery palate.

Medium coarse offwhite head over deep dark red body. Sweetish earthy lightly roasted aroma. Taste is again earthy licorice with smoky roastiness. Smooth dry bitter aftertaste. Very nice. (0.5l bottle.)

Draught: What a lovely beer in a real nice place (Kloster Weltenburg). Very nice, light fruity and malty aroma.  Nice creamy, (yellow to brown head. Reddish-brown color. Fresh, light sweet and malty flavor, light sourly. Full bodied, intensive, very pleasant roasted malt bitterness. Dry bitter finish.
(0.5L Bottle) Pours brown with a tan head. Aroma of sweet caramel. Decent blend of roasted malts also hint at toffee, smoke and fruit. Overall pretty good. A bit sweet, but not bad at all.

Draught from a 5 litre party keg. Dark red, almost brown, with a huge tan head that fades quickly. Low carbonation, which somehow spoiled the palate. The aroma features a fruity yeast. Roasted malt, toffee, nuts in the flavour, also a bit of dark chocolate. The finish is long and smooth. Very drinkable high quality Dunkel.
Nice smell of roasted grain. Full malt taste, a little hops. Good, but not great.
Very good. Very dark brown colour with limited head. sweet taste of caramel and spice.

500 ml bottle. Ruby red. Clear and with a thick fine-laced head. The head falls down quite rapidly, but had this creamy feel to it. The combination of a ruby red beer and a creamy head is really enticing. Sweet malty, very bock-like, aroma. Notes of old leather and toffee. Gentle carbonation with fine soft bubbles. Thick mouthfeel for a beer this low in alcohol. A little hop bitterness can be felt throughout.

Dark red, huge head that falls fast, no laces; Strange nose, deep and warm but initially with tones of cabbage, when the beer gets a little air it turns to brown bread, and a very distinctive fresh barley; Super balanced body, great carbonation, a bit thin; turning into bitter quite long finish, quite simple but very deep mostly malt. All in all a very well balanced beer that could use a bit more character.

ahh a treu and lovely dunkel! smells of caramel and a bit roasted malt. tastes so much better: roasted malt,  caramel, molasse and strangely enough redberries which linger on in the finish. lovely... Thanks Joss
Clean and creamy, with some nice dark bready flavor.  Rich caramel maltiness, slightly roasted with a wonderful mouthfeel, a true pleasure to drink.
Light brown colour with a mostly lasting light brown creamy head. Nice malty aroma and taste. Nice palate. Lasting finish.

Creamy and adherent nut head, optimal persistence. Limpid brown color, rather fine bubbly. Determined and smooth scent with notes of coffee, braced malt and smoked wood. Enough pungent taste with a determined and extended bitter. Soft and little alcoholic final of good persistence.
Bottle. Deep dark brown in color with a tan head. Malty sweet aroma. Caramel notes. Roasty and malty flavor.  Sweet and grainy. Finish is bitter. Smooth mouthfeel Very nice beer. Very drinkable.

Barrel Draft from a wooden cask at the RUFC, Bromsgrove 16/07/2005
Amber coloured and slightly rich on the palate with fruit and wheat aromas. Slightly dry lasting finish.
Pours reddish brown with small dissipating head. Good malty aroma. Nice flavour, but tends to get a bit too sour when it warms up.

Bottled. Poured with a nice thick head. Aroma was a sweet malty scent.  Beautiful dark brown color.   The type of nice malty flavor I enjoy.  Mouthfeel was nice on the tongue, but heavy down the throat; there was a thick sweet,malty aftertaste that stuck to the back of the throat long after taking a sip.  Not bad at all, probably better if paired with a meal.

A dark, chocolatey brown beer with a frothy beige head. A strong toasted malt nose with sweet caramel and wheat elements towards the end. The taste is slightly bitter sweet, with malt and caramel the prominent flavours. There is a slightly winey, acetic aftertaste.

Øllen er en klar maghogni farvet, og har en sød brændt smag, uden at det dog bliver for brændt. Har en let bitter eftersmag.

Smager af mere end øl med denne alcoholprocent normalt gør.

Har ikke voldsomt meget kulsyre.

Skummet er flot lysebrunt, men holder ikke ret længe.

Only 4 mths old 500mL surprisingly enough. Lasting foamy beige mousse covers a chestnut body with orange reflects, blooming with carbonation. First sip keeps the goodness from the aroma on, with gentle fruit acids enhancing drinkability while elegant alt-like leafy noble hops and nutty dryish malts escape anything close to heavy sweetness. As the sipping continues, you figure youd rather keep on with heavy sips and the notion applied rewards you with delightful lacing coating the glass. The carbonation slows down as it warms, diminishing the roasty feel and accentuating the competence of the fruitiness construction - grape, plums, berries . Finishes smooth, tongue-cleansing. Light-medium body doesnt show any wateriness, but definitely feels lagery in its leanness. Very enjoyable, well extracted malts that stretch more toward roastiness and bready toastiness than sweet caramel and bring forth deep, almost vinous pleasurable fruit notes.

Bottled. Pours a medium amber sort of color. Sweet chocolate aroma. Some roasted maltiness as well. More sweet chocolate flavor upon the first sip. Lots of roasted malty bitterness to balance out the sweet. Finish is bitter and roasty with a hint of sweet. Nice dunkel.

This bottled brew poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized mostly lasting light brown colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body contained average carbonation, was transparent and copper brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of malty sweet .  Its mouth feel is initially smooth sweet malt with a lingering  mellow palate and a mild sweet malt caramel aftertaste.  Its flavor contained malty sweet  notes and was yummy.  A nice all-around session brew.
On tap. Brown colour with a rich head. Malty aroma with some notes of roastedness. Very nice smooth flavour with some little roasted notes, malty and very little hoppy.

(500 ml bottle from http://hitimewine.com, marked "02.01.02 P) Pours an orangish brown, has a foamy but solid biscuit head. Aroma is malt, some brown sugar, maybe hay. Some lacing. A little thin, also a bit dry. Flavor of roasted malt and some brown sugar. Moderately bitter finish. Pretty good, reminds me of a brown ale but drier and a little less sweet.

Dark brown with a tall pillowy head. Terrific aromas of fresh brown bread and caramel. Rich roasted malt palate with sweet flavours of brown sugar and toffee balanced by a slightly woody character. Delicious.

text: (Bottle 50 cl) Dark brown with a huge, brownish head that simply refuses to dissipate. Soft and smooth with notes of roasted malt and only a discreet hint of hops. Typical South German dark lager - very delicious. 020503

Darl ruby mahogany crystal clear with medium size lasting mixed suds and fine bubbles, mid beige colour head. Lightly smoked sweet brown rice malts coffee soapy aroma. Thin soft mouthfeel. Flavour wise its a pleasant enough brew, mostly sweet malts and bit of bitte hops at the end. I would like to see a little more intensity in everything but I guess that is part of the lighter dunkel style. Very similar to the Weihenstephaner dunkel but maybe with a slightly better aroma. I guess Im not a real straight dunkel fan.

Bought at Fenaknoken in Oslo, Norway.  41 NOK for 500 ml bottle.  Excellent dark lager.  Nutty malt, nice balance of sweet and bitter.  Very tasty.  Plum.  I enjoyed it on its own, but might go well with red meat.

(500 ml bottle: $2.29 at Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA) This cant be right.  I just bought this bottle recently, and I see the date on the bottle is 11-Feb-2001.  Wow, it sure seems like dunkels handle aging extremely well because this is another example of a beer that is supposedly well past its prime that still tastes great.  Well, maybe its not a great tasting beer, but its solid enough and doesnt seem negatively impacted by the age.  It has that familiar and very welcomed dark, toasty, slightly chocolaty maltiness that seems common in German dunkels.  This one seems slightly sweeter than the others Ive tried, but that doesnt make it less enjoyable.  Light bitterness tags along for the ride nearly unnoticed.  Oddly enough, despite being quite flavorful, this isnt a very aromatic beer, showing only a modest amount of toasty and earthy maltiness.  This gently carbonated beer has a medium body.  Medium brown in color and quite clear in appearance, the crown is light tan, creamy and well over an inch in height on the pour.  As it slowly settles to a thin, complete layer, it leaves only a few small patches of lace on the glass.  Well, this is the last of the nine Weltenburger beers Ive sampled that is imported into the U.S., and I think Ive saved one of the best for last.  A solid dunkel packing lots of flavor and enjoyment.  Although the age may have something to do with that as it seems to me that with dunkels, aging intensifies the malt flavors.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2005 500 ml bottle, bought in Bier Spezi Hamburg. Clear brown to copper coloured, large light tan head. Pleasant aroma of lightly roasted malts, caramel, chocolate and bakery (including rye bread and Danish pastry). Lightly roasted malty flavour, fairly mellow, bready notes, some caramel but not really sweet, decent hops for a dunkel. Mouthfeel could have been fuller. Moderate but pleasant aftertaste. Okay.
(Bottle at Fynske Øldage) Malty and burnt sugar. Clear dark amber color. Thin mouthfeel. Bready, malty flavor. Like malt candy. Same goes for the palate.

As dunkels go, this was on the heavier end.  Notes of coffee and cocoa, more sweet than dry, with nuttiness and bitter nut astringency and grassiness in the finish.  Large slowly receding head.  Some roastiness (mild).  I like my dunkels a little drier, but this was nice.

Rich, dark syrup aroma.  Moderately sweet, roasty, almost like a Baltic porter.  Nice label and bottle, mahagony beer, slightly off-white head.  Molasses richness.  This was pretty well-balanced, but roasty and flavorful. Not bad.  A turn of metal and astringency dings the palate slightly.

Bottled.
Clear red coloured with a small off white head.
Aroma of malts, dark bread and caramel.
Sweet flavour of malts, caramel and dark bread with notes of dried fruits.
Tastes more like a bock than a dunkel.
Good dunkel !

Poured a dark brown, with good size light-brown head. Not a lot of lacing, but the head was mostly lasting. Body was clear, with no particles.

This beer smelled and tasted of molasses through and through. Some dough, maybe sweat on the aroma. Light sweetness on the palate, not too acidic - well balanced, with average finish. Medium body, slightly creamy texture, soft carbonation, with a touch of tannin on the finish. 

Very easy to drink, like most German brews, gone before you want to finish. From a bottle I brought to the US from the brewery. Drank a few months after freshness date, whcih was 4-15-05.
Amber with a nice offwhite head. Milky vanilla aroma with nuts and some fruity notes. Malty, fruity flavor with some raisins. Maybe it lacks some body.
Bottled. Dark brown beer with brownish head. Very malty and fruity. Finish is not very bitter, but dominated by malt and raisins. A good classic dunkel.

Huge frothy white head over a dark reddish brown beer.  Nose of sweet malt and chocolate; taste of sweet malt, toffee, chocolate, and coffee.  I could do with a bit more intensity and a bit more hoppy bitterness, but it is not really reasonable to expect every dark German beer to be Celebrator, and this one is low enough in alcohol to use as a session beer rather than as the centerpiece of the evening.

Beautiful translucent chestnut brown in color with a booming, frothy and tan shaded head.  Aroma is simple but splendid: chocolate, mild coffee, copper and unsalted pecans.  Flavor continues the elegant simplicity, calling on rich chocolate, caramel and roasted malts.  Flavor transitions to chocolate covered toffee on the tail end of each sip.  Creamy and mild palate feel and a malt profile that could put on a clinic.  Finishes like light chocolate mocha wafers.  Impressive.
Pours a beautiful brown with nice lacing.  Aroma is molasses and malt.  Flavor is akin to the aroma, but a bit watery.  Too watered down for my taste; needs more assertiveness.

text: Bottle. Malty aroma. Hint of oxidization? Dark brown colour, small stable head. Malty, slightly roasted flavour. Slightly sweet. Nice dunkel.

Brown ruby body, untroubled, with a small light beige head. Roasted nuts and caramels nose, without smokiness. Chocolate, caramel and malt flavors pour into the mouth. They are very well balanced in a medium carbonated body. Finish is sweet and lasting, but not overpowering. An excellent dunkel close to greatness.

Delightful Dunkel this one turned out to be. Had a bottle sitting around for quite some time and decided it was as good a night as any to finally crack it. Poured into a weissbier glass, deep reddish brown (very red!) with a short lather of beige foam that left some legs as I drank. Rich and inviting grated chocolate and toasted malt nose, with a hint of teramisú dessert, dark ripe fruits and roasted nuts. Fierce malt in the mouth, unexpected of a Dunkel, medium-light bodied and medium in carbonation which moved things along nicely. Sweet burnt sugars upfront, woody and toasted malt flavours mid-palate and a strong dose of mocha-latte and plums that followed into the long, meaty, malty swallow. Very clean, balanced and good to the last mouthful. I expected a great dark lager from this historic brewer and it certainly delivered. A lovely drop. (500mL bottle, 10/08/05)

Flavoursome German dunkel. Poured a deep chestnut colour with a garnet tint and a 1cm head that sizzled and laced before  it collapsed. There are lots of dark fruit in the aroma - raisins, plums - and some underlying molasses, chocolate and fresh bread. Quite an oily mouthfeel, moderate carbonation. Bit thin in the body. Spicier than I expected, with strong chocolate notes and a robust finish for its 4.7% alcohol. Plenty of sweet dark malt. (500ml bottle, International Beer Shop, Perth)

Roasted malt aroma with some mild chocolate. Copper brown color with a fly white head yo! Fo shizzle. Again with the German trademark:  lotta malt with sone caramel and molasses flavors. One dimensional, but how many German beers arent? It still manages to be a very drinkable beer.

Bottle marked 04-02-05. Poured a medium sized ivory head that was mostly lasting, fair lacing, fine-small sized bubbles, carbonated, transparent, and a red hue. Aroma was malty, caramel and sweet. Sweet, malty, caramel and some chocolate. Smooth palate.

Draught in Germany.
Dark brown with white head, almost diminishing. Aroma moderate malty (brown sugar, bread) and light hoppy. Flavor moderate sweet, light bitter. Body light to medium, oily, soft carbonated.

It has a beautiful mahogany color and a lightly sweet brown sugar aroma.  The aroma, however, was way too faint for my tastes.  The was virtually no head and it dissapated very quickly.  The taste was nothing to write the Monestery about.  The flavor was entirely too watery with the sole flavors being roasted and overly roasted one.  I wont be purchasing this one again.  Big disappointment.

The flavor is caramel, cocoa and raisins. A bit of let down. Lively carbonation, medium body. Ok but it is no Capital Dunkel.
Reddish brown in color with a creamy off white head.  Rich caramel, coffee, chocolate aroma.  Dark roasted malt flavor with hints of bitter bakers chocolate.  A dunkel with plenty of character.

Bottle.  Nice dark brown with hints of red decent pour nice carbonation.  Excellent light caramel and malt flavor not overly sweet but just well balanced.  Excellent.  A come back to kind of dark beer.
Bottle. A strong malty aroma of chocolate and coffee. Dark reddish brown color with nice head. A sweet carmelly flavor and a wonderful balance.  One of the best dunkles I have ever had!
Bottled. Dark brown/ruby colour with beige bubbly head. Halfbitter caramellish nose with weak malty notes. Roasted sugar, old coffee and caramel in flavour. Sticky palate.

Bottle.  Nice brown pour with a relatively thin brown head.  Looks like the Doppelbock.  Smells like chocolate, caramel and coffee.  The taste was great for a low alcohol beer with a terrific caramel and wine mouthfeel.  What a pleasant surprise.

(on bottle; thanx Yogi) Brandy brown, maybe at bit darker. Aroma of malts and a twik of sour mash. The coarbonation is high, but is balanced good by a fist full of good malts. Has a child-like, milkchocolately finish; my kid at 1 year diged it a lot.

Pours a deep dark brown and mostly hazy with a moderate head and good lacing.  Aroma is at first- sweet and slightly aromatic/munich malt.  Then turns to caramel and a hint of fruitiness and chocolate.  Flavor has a lot of munich and choclate with just a hint of bitter hops in the end to make it smooth.  Very nice dunkel.  Im sure this was on the shelf for a while but somehow it tasted really fresh- just like the ones I used to drink in germany.
Bottle.  A chocolate and coffee malt aroma.  Reddish brown color with small head.  Sweet chocolate malt flavor with only slight bitterness.  Not a great deal of body.  Nice but on the weak side.

This beer looks picture perfect in the glass, but its all downhill from there. The nose is mainly spicy (classic German herbs). The palate is dry light and drinkable, but lacks any real German malt character. A nice dark lager, but this beers lacks too many key elements.

From A Bottle.Auburn in colour with a large head,aroma is of malt and biscuit,
taste is of dark malt,some chocolate and toffee.

Bottled.  A dark reddy brown coloured beer with no head.  The aroma has caramel, chocolate and a little licquorice.  The taste is fairly sweet and nutty with caramel, licquorice and toffee.  It is medium bodied and leans toward a weaker version of the Asam Bock.  Tasty.

Dirty brown body with a nice off white head.  Rich, bready aromas with lots of crystal malt and graham cracker.  Full and rich on the palate.  Flavors are just like the nose would lead you to expect, just it leans a bit toward being too sweet.  Overall, pretty nice, but I dont know if Id buy it again.

Body was a deep red with soft carbonation topped with a creamy, light-tan head that faded quickly. Moderate roasted malt aroma with mild hints of coffee, wood and plums. Moderate bitterness from start to finish with a burnt malt compliment. Medium bodied (although slightly watery) with a chalky finish.
