(bottle) The name is program. A very flavoursome Dunkel. Dark red-copper coloured with a tanned head. Complex aroma of roasted malts, coffee and herbal hops with hints of resinous wood. Initially fine toasted malts rounded up with aromatic hops and a very dry & bitter (for a Dunkel), lasting aftertaste.

Great appearance in the glass. A deep ruby colour and and fine clean head. There is a lot of toffee and caramel here with what seems to be a toasted pinenut aroma. The flavour and mouthfeel are smooth, smooth and smooth. Subtle chocolate malt and a low hop that could make for a slightly cloying beer if consumed in great quantity. This is not to be considered a fault though and as a result this is a fine beer for the occasional tipple.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Pouring a deep brown color with ruby highlights, this has a creamy, tall tan head and a rich caramel and toffee aroma.  Medium bodied and smooth to drink, this has the mentioned strong malt flavors, a touch of woodiness, and some hop bitterness in the finish.  Im not a big dunkel fan, but this is nice.
(Bottle) Dark brown colour, light brownish head. Nosi is malty, toasted, coffee powder, light chocolate.  Roasted malt flavour, well balanced, tasty. Medium body, light texture, easy to drink.
This beer is available on tap in the loreley restaurant located in the Phoenix Club, Anaheim
(Bottle)  Pours a clear mahogany body with a mmedium-sized, creamy beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt and caramel.  Roasted malt flavor.  Dry finish.

Simple bock-like nose with sweet malty tones. Transulent lightmahagony color with fairly nice head. Malty, nutty with a knid of skunkish aftertaste--not necessarily bad nut watered down flavor. Slightly bittered with hops. Palate is decent but still kind of watered down. Not very impressed.

Nice clear brown pour with aromas of molasses and caramel. Taste is chocolate with some sweet caramel. I usually dont go for this style as I find them too sweet but this stuff had somewhat of a hop bite to it. Smooth and creamy with some oak in the finish. Well done.

This dunkel pours with a deep amber body topped by a thick head with a good amount of lacing.  The aroma and flavor are sweet and malty with a nice bitter hoppiness and a touch of caramel.  Medium bodied, smooth and slightly dry.
Pours a clear amber/brown hue with a frothy off-white head with nice lacing.  Aromas of malt, copper, and roasted nuts.  Favors are very light with some smokiness, with a skunked finish.

yummy beer, thanks mullet. deep clear brown-red, lighter than some dunkels. smell is mostly woody munich malt with some toastiness and fresh wort smells, with also quite a lot of herbal, minty hops. flavour is creamy date sweetness, drying out with a long aromatic hop finish with a touch of chocolate and a touch of quenching acidity. not a lot of roast here but just enough to seem like a natural extension of the munich malt. fairly light bodied, but nowhere near thin in flavour. the quality of the weltenburger hops shine through here like they do in the pils - delicious leafy quinine/minty/oregano flavours lingering in the finish. this beer might be accused of lacking guts compared to some more roasty, thick soupy dunkels, but i really like the hoppy dryness. yum.

Honey/cola coloured body with a good-size fairly lasting tan head. Meaty brothy aroma. Burnt grain taste along with bonox, malt and a hint of chocolate and caramel, good body feel with a smooth start that carries through to the finish.
Nice dark colour. For me a hard to define taste, a litlle bitter, yet sweet. Nice aroma. Nice aftertaste. Complex.

Cola colour with a persistent beige head. Very sweet and bready aroma. Big roasted malt flavour which is only slightly burnt at the end. I usually dont like dunkels because the ones Ive had have been one dimensional. This is more complex and better.

Great deep red-brown colour with brilliant clarity. Good head retention. 
Aroma of molasses jumps out and dominates - to the point of being slightly off-putting - followed by brown bread, cinnamon, milo, honey and ice cream. 
Big spicy, grainy maltiness with nice subtle roast and a slight bitterness. Definitely bock-like (reminded me of Salvator). I must say I always thought the description of dunkels as "earthy" was a bit weird but this one certainly fits the bill.
Well made and nice, but not outstanding.

bottled. dark deep ruby colour. rich cocoa, prune and cream aroma, maybe a little black forest cake in there. plenty of guts and doppelbock character. some golden syrup flavour and a little sourness and faint hint of smokiness. light passionfruit in the finish. classy stuff, i love dunkels like this
Dark reddish colour with average off-white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with some caramel and dark fruits. Flavor has a light sweetness with notes of roasted malts. dry bitter finish.

Dark ruby-red colour. Quickly diminsihing head. Aroma is malty of the caramalt variety. Tastes caramelly, malty, like bavarian malt candy (though, I guess that won´t tell most people much), but not that sweet. Light to medium-bodied. Not the best Dunkel I´ve had, but still good.
Pours brownish ruby red with moderate head.  Sweet, bready yet caramel  nose.  Flavor rich with maltiness with mild sweetness.  Nice clean finish.

a nice rich sipping beer.  I found this in my fathers frig or all places, so i can only assume it was part of some export beer package and the label scared him.  It was very full bodied for a dunkel,  and my cheif complaint would be its richness.  Still not that bad at all

Pours a dark red with a foamy ivory head. Very sweet malty aroma with a faint chocolate thing goin on. Taste is rich and malty, slightly roasty with a dark chocolate hint in the finish. Very smooth and sweet.
Red brown color, light sweet malty aroma and taste, medium body, bitter dry finish.

Sweet chocolate aroma. Color is dark brown, little head. Chocolate flavor dominates the start, ending is strongly hopped which makes it very dryand flowery. Carbonation comes up nicely, also body feels good enough. Nice brew, maybe little bland starting though.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2013 Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is medium to dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (whole grain bread, toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.  Very plain/simple rendition, but ok.  Liquid bread indeed.
(RBSG04) Clear copper body with off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, caramel, floral, bread, orange.  Taste is medium sweet, caramel, honey, some floral, peach.  Light-medium body.
RBSG 2004:  Brownish orange with a small white head.  Light bread and cokkie malts, starts and ends lightly sweet.  Medium fizzy body.
Bottle.  Brownish-red.  Quite stale; rotten wood in the aroma and flavor.  Not much head; the crispness is the only real redeeming feature.  Not a great example of the style.
ruby/amber color with a creamy head and sheet lacing. Hoppy aroma. Malts are mostly caramel or toffee. Caramel big in the flavor. Peppery hops. Smooth palate, slightly fuzzy.
Quite chocolaty aroma, bit to much.... Chocolate like flavor but more mild.... Chocolate/alcohol finish...
Clear brown color, medium lasting off-white head. Aroma of some roasted malts with rye and fine selected hops. Taste is caramelly and sticky bittersweet with a sticky mouthfeel.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Deep reddish brown with a moderate tan foamy head, no lacing. Yeasty and caramel aroma. Slightly roasty and caramel in the taste. Medium bodied. Very smooth, very nice. Very good dunkel.
Decent head. Dark brown. Smoke and salt aroma. Lightly sour smoke flavour. To style but unremarkable.
Aroma of chocolate, hops. Pours a dark copper brown, thin brown head. Nothing that really stands out. Brown sugar aftertaste. Mouthfeel is a bit thin. Average.

Reddish brown with a thick tan foam; EXTREMELY appetizing fresh bread and forest aromas. Slightly roasty at first, broadening into an appetizing, smooth, and very clean dunkel lager One of the best imported versions Ive tasted on US soil, it survived the trip extremely well, plus from what I remember of drinking it in Regensburg a few years back, damn good to begin with!

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2007 8 June 2003 (Rerated 29 Apr 06)  - Sweet malt and wheat  aroma. Clear brown-red colour, lovely light creamy brown head with a lasting lacing. Dark ruby brown color. Roasted dark choc with some mocha aroma. Nice malty soft palate and slight bitterness. Smokey malt and smooth easy drinking dark beer. Slight sweet aftertaste and  smoked hoppy finish.

Yikes, this was pretty good. Wow, let me tell you this was pretty cool. Had it at this german restauraunt in Gibson City. Very cool atmosphere and stuff. So if you are cruising down I-75 and you pass PAXTON Illinois exit, it is well worth the 15 min detour. NOW FOR THE BEER: Dark dark brown with a thin quickly discipating tan head. The nose is very roasted with malts and caramel. The taste is nearly the same, roastedness malts almost dirty. But this was thick and full and just plain ol wonderful.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2004 Aroma of moderate roasted malts, caramel/coffee and fruits. Clear, brown coloured with a lasting brown head. Taste is malty-sweet, fruity, a little thin/watery and hoppy-bitter. Decent Dunkel
Dark brown colour, nice head and lace. Mouthwatering, very malty aroma. Taste is malty and with some hop-flavor. Nice dunkel.

Bottled: Dark amber/cobber coloured. Clear. Dark beige lasting dense head. Malty with light cocoa notes in the aroma. Flavour is full and malty. Caramel notes is present. Is light fruity and has some vague roasted notes. Is light bitter in the end. Decent dunkel.
if you like chokolat and caramel this is a beer werth traing. but i dont like drinking my candy......
Dark brown with a medium-sized firm head. Sweet and malty flavour of dark chocolate, ryebread and caramel. Sweet flavour cocoa, caramel, chocolate and herbs. Sweet flavour of chocolate in finish.

50 cl bottle; served in Nastro Azzurro glass.
Reddish-brown; decent head. Dark malt and a slight, hoppy freshness in the aroma. Pleasant, rounded taste w/ a slightly sweet malt presence, some hop presence, and a long finish. Pleasant mouthfeel.

Copper in color with a beige head.  Found the aroma and the flavor to be complex.  Fruit, chocolate, caramel, coffee.  Hints of many things as I sniffed but nothing stood out.  In any event, the aroma was pleasing and inviting and the flavor was rewarding.  Unusual example of the style but a good drink.

Bottled (label says alc. 4.7%)
Small creamy off-white head. Dark ruby brown color. Crisp malty aroma. Taste is typical dunkel with roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Soft finish, slightly hoppy. Very well-balanced beer. I really had to look for more Weltenburger Kloster beers, because this seems to be quality brewery!
This really was a nice dunkel.Lovely ruby red colour with a decent size head.Nice malty taste with a hint of fruit.Decent body as well.This was a really enjoyable beer.

Perfect dunkel from the oldest Monastery Brewery in the world (1050)Plenty of time to get this right!!Not as heavy as some dunkels but smooth with a pleasant malt character suggesting cookies. Toasty, smokey finish. Great with spicy meats like wursts!

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2007 (Bottled) Clear, very dark reddish brown color with a smallish, beige, lightly lacy head. Sweetish-malty, lightly syrupy aroma with mild, sourish roastiness. Roasted, pretty malty, sweetish flavor with rye and low bitterness and a slightly acidic finish. At least medium-bodied, smooth palate with lowish carbonation. A very basic, not very complex, but nicely balanced and pleasantly smooth brew. A lighter version of the great Asam Bock.
(1/27/2004, was 6-4-7-3-13=3.3) Dark brown color, no head to speak of. Malty aroma with herbs and rye bread. Smooth, malty, a bit sweet flavor. Bitter finish. Quite full-bodied for its ABV. A good dunkel.
Full, malty flavor, very smooth, nice brown color, dry finish, low bitterness

Ah a dunkel, i love that name.  Has an oaken brown color to it with a mod off white head.  a lill dark wheat bread and walnuts in the aroma and pretty much in the flava, and its got those dark qualities while remaining quite smooth and refreshing.

Pours a rich dark brown with a thick light tan head.  Complex sugary sweet caramel and toffee aroma.  Sweet caramel malty body with some chocolate notes and bready yeastiness.  Sticky sweet finish has a chocolate chip cookie feel to it.  Very enjoyable, thanks BierBauch!
dark petrified wood & mohagany colored..with a solid tan head..sweet, nutty, satisfying nose...sweet & cakey..with some caramel and nutty flavors..yet light bodied and refreshing.
Very dark brown with a tan head and some lacing. Bready malty nose and taste. Full on the palate. The taste was bigger than expected.
Lightish dunkel with a small head, slight malty aroma and  watery malt flavour.  Overall a very average beer.

Fine roasty caramel aroma.
Red amber, lowish head.
Powerfull chocolate roastiness, a bit
sweet honey,
finetuned bitterhops.
A really nice beer.
A perfect dunkel: almost black in color with light beige head, very malty and earthy. Amazingly drinkable.
Dark brown color with a light brown head.  Plum nose and some alcohol.  Old spider webs.  Thick sweet sticky flavors.  Malt grains whole oats.  Earthy.
Wonderful stuff.  Slight chocolate/coffee palate but not overbearing.  Another of my favorites that's hard to find.  Brewed in the Weltenburger Kloister in Bavaria.  These monks know their beer!

Rasins and mollasses in both nose and flavour, some burnt toast. Creamy and raisiny palate, with some nice burnt bitterness in the finish, some roast, slight;y sticky and sweet, pleasant dunkel however.
Bottled. Nut brown with rich head, fruty malt aroma. Sweet and very firm. Raisiny with wonderfully deep malt character and grassy finish with low- medium bitterness.

Bottle. Nice wet leather aroma. Nice dark malt flavour with some licorice in the finish. Fairly straightforward and easy to drink. Not really my thing. I can't quite put my finger on why. There is a similarity between this and a mild. I like mild, but I don't quite get the same pleasure from this.

Pours a beautiful copper color with a massive beige head. the aroma and flavor was nutty for sure, but there seemed to be an off metallic character to the beer at first...as it warmed it went away. Sweet tones rounded out the nuttiness just fine. A tad bit watery feel. Nice session ale.

Dark ruby in color and with caramel and some coffee/chocolate tones, but much lighter in respect to what I had anticipated. Good malt characteristics coming through, but perhaps muted in comparison to many other Bavarian beers. Very nice and very drinkable.

A nutbrown beer with a small head. The aroma is sweet, wheaty, nutty, and brewmashy. The falvor is very brewmashy you can almost taste the straws of the grain - it is pretty carbonated and bitter with hints of woodiness. The aftertaste is a good slightly smoked lingering bitterness. The palate is both light and heavy - a very complex beer.
Amber red in color. Small head. Mild malty taste with hints of choclate and maybe coffe. Very pleasent!
I found lots of plum fruity sweetness in this, mixed in with some roast and toffee flavors.  Smooth and lighter bodied than the color hints at.  This was nice and drinkable.

Toasted caramelly malt nose, dark amber color, low tight head. Nice roasted malt body with toffee flavors turning tobacco-like toward the end. Thinish and fizzy. Nice rounded blend of taste in an accessible dark beer.
Yummie, so good! Malt and pure coffee beans nose. Amber - more red color with a little head. Malt, chocolate and espresso taste - wonderful. Long lasting medium bitter finísh.
Reddish brown, light head formation. Molass/soy/fishy aroma> fruity front palate, with a licorice and chocolate second half. Slight meatiness in the finish. Drinks relatively easily.
Dark brown-red in colour.  This has a good mouthfeel along with a deep malty taste.  There is a touch of chocolate and a bitter finish.  Recommended.

Up to now the best Dunkel I have had.
To really enjoy it go to the Biergarten in Kelheim
Chocolate dry malt aroma and flavor.Kind of like asam bocks dryer brother.Clean chocolate malt finish.

Dark brown color, slightly sweet malty aroma. A mild bodied dunkel. Mild taste. Nice malt flavor. Well balanced. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Nice

Dark and fairly thick. I must admit I dont see why others are calling it thin.  Flavor was the closest thing I have come across in a beer that compares to chewing on roasted barley.  Fairly sweet with caramel present.  No discernable hop presence.  Quite fine.
Watery and quite bland. A huge dissapointment!
Malty, dark but mild with some molasses, opens at 56-7F. A light-medium bodied brew.
Malty aroma, chocolate and raisins. Malty, but not too sweet taste. Coffee, caramel, chocolate, raisins and banana. A bit thinnish. A well made dunkel, clean, fruity and fairly complex. Recommended.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2003 It blew away the other Munich Dunkels I tasted because it's mild, not bitter and appropriately complex.  It's a bit bock-ish and sweet.  Quite good, but unusual for its style.  There's a slight roastiness present.
Very clean.  Nice toasted, smokey, roast malt flavor.  Very enjoyable.
A nice Munich dunkel with a sweet malty flavor. Lightish and smooth to drink.
I cant understand the high ratings of this one. My example was  nothing special in taste. Gave a Cola-feelig because of both the colour and the head, and because it was highly carbonated.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 Bottle@Home. Strong malty aroma with chocolate, raisin and prune. Brown color, off-white head, good lace. Light sweet, malty, bitter, roasted, chocolate, light coffee, caramel. Medium body. Very good example of the style.
If you want a very good dark german beer thats not as rich or complex as a doppelbock then this beer is for you. Good balance.
Full, malty, very smooth and beginning to dry out towards the finish.
